Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Hi, 
In `cli` (ubuntu)  how can I see if I'm running the etomic version or regular?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Hi @CrisF Is your question related to BarterDex?

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @TonyL  Hi, yes it is.

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
@CrisF you can check version in package.json file which you can find in folder with BarterDex.
If version is >= 1.0.1 etomic should be already included

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @TonyL  Thank you! I'll check when I get back.

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @TonyL I think I made a mistake.  It isn't BarterDEX.  It's `komodo-cli`.

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
@CrisF Did you run `komodod` before or you're using Agama in Native mode?
And could you please clarify what do you mean by etomic version of komodo-cli - maybe you meant electrum?

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: Etomic is an asset chain which using as an proxy token for ETH/ERC20 trading, so it's not very related to `komodo-cli` and `komodo-cli` don't have any specific etomic-version

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
@TonyL Hi, I managed to figure out the problem.
Coin daemons were running. 
I was getting a could not parse error when starting `./client`.
Couldn't remember what version I was running.  The `client` is slightly different for each version.
It turns out had an extra `space` in there that I was missing when checking through it.
All good now :)
Thanks for your help!

Author: TonyL#3577
Content: @CrisF Glad to hear that problem is resolved on your end!

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
I think this version needs to disable the update part of  the `client` script, or it updates the regular non-etomic version and causes problems.
https://github.com/KomodoPlatform/KomodoPlatform/wiki/Step-by-Step-Setup-Guide-for-ETH-(ERC20)-Token-Swap-Using-barterDEX

Author: CrisF#3405
Content:
Actually I think I'm running this version
https://github.com/artemii235/SuperNET/tree/etomic

Content: this document version Is for eth/erc20 token version if  you follow exact steps, I mean the client script

Author: CrisF#3405
Content: @Nabob, Thanks, it's working now üòÉ

Content:
komodod.log: ...Agama-linux-x64/resources/app/assets/bin/linux64/komodod: /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcurl.so.4: version `CURL_OPENSSL_3' not found (required by /media/charlie/sdd3t/crypto/KMD/Agama-linux-x64/resources/app/assets/bin/linux64/komodod)
komodod exited with code 1, crashed?

Author: CMaurice#1685
Content: let me know if I'm doing anything inappropriate, first time on Discord

Author: CMaurice#1685

Content: you need to uninstall libcurl4 and try to install libcurl3

Content: Genuine thanks Nabob,  but I believe this will break my system

Content: in ubuntu, 18.04, we have this dependency,  for timebeing for any other connecting applications you can create soft link for libcurl.so.4.

Content: ln -s /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcurl.so.4 /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libcurl.so.3

Author: Nabob#5004
Content: may be that trick never works, you may need to keep libcurl3

Author: TonyL#3577
Content:
It's looks like a problem with double slash which was fixed few days ago but it's not merged to KomodoPlatform/komodo master branch yet as I can see.
@CMaurice If you're using KomodoPlatform/komodo  repo you may it build from `dev` branch
```
git reset --hard
git checkout dev
git pull
./zcutil/build.sh -j$(nproc)
```

Author: Nabob#5004
Content: @TonyL  He Is referring to Agama Linux Portable build, not  the cli build

Author: SHossain#0007
Content: only solution i found working is, installing the `libcurl3` package for this issue using `sudo apt-get install libcurl3`

Author: CMaurice#1685
Content: ok, so might try and build cli later, but prefer look of the Agama Portable

Author: SHossain#0007
Content:
try using the command separately, rather than running all at same line. 
```
brew tap discoteq/discoteq; brew install flock
brew install autoconf autogen automake
brew install gcc6
brew install binutils
brew install protobuf
brew install coreutils
brew install wget
brew install nanomsg
```

Author: Shinzo Abe#9369
Content: @SHossain what is so bad in using root@ setup

Author: SHossain#0007
Content:
**About Root**
The root user is the administrative user in a Linux environment that has very broad privileges. Because of the heightened privileges of the root account, you are actually discouraged from using it on a regular basis. This is because part of the power inherent with the root account is the ability to make very destructive changes, even by accident.
